update.description:
This is a new math class called SignalStats that computes incremental statistics on signals (see [gazebo_design document](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/default/signal_stats/signal_stats.md) for more detail). I used this extensively for the accuracy tests and refined the API to minimize the lines of code required for implementation. I think it can be useful in integration tests as well and have converted the `INTEGRATION_physics_inertia_ratio` test as an example. It's especially useful in reducing console spam by replacing expectations inside of loops with a single expectation outside the loop.

I will make a separate pull request to ignition-math.
update.title: New math class SignalStats

content.raw:
I just re-ran the coverage build with the most recent changes and
[SignalStats has 100% coverage](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/48/clover-report/_var_lib_jenkins_workspace_gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64_gazebo_gazebo_math/SignalStats_cc.html),
but [Vector3Stats only has 71.4% coverage](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/48/clover-report/_var_lib_jenkins_workspace_gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64_gazebo_gazebo_math/Vector3Stats_cc.html).
I don't have any tests for the `Vector3Stats::[XYZ]() const` functions.
content.html: I just re-ran the coverage build with the most recent changes and SignalStats has 100% coverage, but Vector3Stats only has 71.4% coverage. I don't have any tests for the Vector3Stats::[XYZ]() const functions.

content.raw: Would the compiler still call all the functions or would it skip them if any return false?
content.html: Would the compiler still call all the functions or would it skip them if any return false?

content.raw: I had a plan for embedding the short name of the statistic within a longer set of names separated by `_` characters. My thought was to use CamelCase for the statistic names (see `"MaxAbs"` in SignalMaxAbsoluteValue). I suppose I could use lowerCamelCase instead (`maxAbs`). I'll switch to that.
content.html: I had a plan for embedding the short name of the statistic within a longer set of names separated by _ characters. My thought was to use CamelCase for the statistic names (see "MaxAbs" in SignalMaxAbsoluteValue). I suppose I could use lowerCamelCase instead (maxAbs). I'll switch to that.

Some lines less:

if (this->dataPtr->stats.empty())
  return 0;

return this->dataPtr->stats.front()->Count();

extra point: before the return, GZ_ASSERT(this->dataPtr->stats.front()->Count() > 0);

content.raw:
This could be simplified to:

`return this->x.InsertStatistics(_names) && this->y.InsertStatistics(_names) && this->z.InsertStatistics(_names) && this->mag.InsertStatistics(_names);`
content.html:
This could be simplified to:

return this->x.InsertStatistics(_names) && this->y.InsertStatistics(_names) && this->z.InsertStatistics(_names) && this->mag.InsertStatistics(_names);

content.raw: It can be easier on future developers to make strings like this all lowercase.
content.html: It can be easier on future developers to make strings like this all lowercase.

content.raw: Yeah, extra source files are fine.
content.html: Yeah, extra source files are fine.

content.raw: Arg, I just noticed that the `InsertData` in SignalRootMenaSquare is always pow 2, so no negative numbers. We don't need the check there then.
content.html: Arg, I just noticed that the InsertData in SignalRootMenaSquare is always pow 2, so no negative numbers. We don't need the check there then.

content.raw: `this->dataPtr->data` is being updated using `InsertData()` method but there is no check for inserting negative values so we potentially end up with a negative result of `this->dataPtr->data / this->dataPtr->count`. If we don't allow negative values in InsertData, it could help to add a check there. It is usually a good measure of QA to check always for positive values when calling sqrt.
content.html: this->dataPtr->data is being updated using InsertData() method but there is no check for inserting negative values so we potentially end up with a negative result of this->dataPtr->data / this->dataPtr->count. If we don't allow negative values in InsertData, it could help to add a check there. It is usually a good measure of QA to check always for positive values when calling sqrt.

content.raw: being pedantic, we could change unsigned int by size_t
content.html: being pedantic, we could change unsigned int by size_t

content.raw: _data could be const
content.html: _data could be const

content.raw: _data could be const
content.html: _data could be const

In order to PIMPL'ize Vector3Stats, I had to split the Vector3Stats class into its own set of header and source files (I couldn't declare SignalStats objects in the same private header file as the SignalStatsPrivate class). I did this in 465073c (branch signal_stats_4.0_pimpl).

The alternative is private attributes with inline accessors (2b604dc branch signal_stats_4.0_inline).

@nkoenig I assume you prefer the PIMPL approach, even if it adds an extra set of source files? I wasn't sure how to generalize from scalar to vector signals, but I wanted the convenience since we use Vector3's quite a bit in the physics code.

content.raw:
I took a look at what you did with the Vector3 class in ign-math with inlined accessors. I don't think I would be able to use inline accessors in combination with PIMPL, since the inline accessors must be defined in the header file.

So do you prefer inlined accessors or a PIMPL design pattern?
content.html:
I took a look at what you did with the Vector3 class in ign-math with inlined accessors. I don't think I would be able to use inline accessors in combination with PIMPL, since the inline accessors must be defined in the header file.

So do you prefer inlined accessors or a PIMPL design pattern?
